div1.p: United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for Gwoo Shee Ah Look. } No. 2647 Filed April , 1914.
Wilbur & Spencer of Portland, Ore., A. L. Clark, or Portland Ore., Jesse A. Frye, of Seattle, Wash., For Petitioner.
Clay Allen, U.S. District Attorney, Geo. F. Fishburne, Assistant District Atty. For Respondent.

A writ of habeas corpus was issued in this case on the 13th day of January, 1914, upon the application of the petitioner, to which return has been made. The return shows that on the 5th day of November, 1913, a warrant for arrest of Gwoo Shee Ah Look was issued, and she was taken into custody. It would appear that a general raid was made on November 4th, 1913, of the city of Portland by the police officers of the city, and the petitioner together with some other women were arrested. A report was made to the immigration commissioner of the arrest of the petitioner, and she was taken into custody under the warrant above stated and given a hearing. On the same day the commissioner was advised by Mr. Clark, representing the firm of Wilbur & Spencer, laywers, that they had been retained on behalf of Gwoo Shee Ah Look, and desired to consult with her. This request was denied, as were also the subsquent requests which were made practically every day until after the 17th day of November when all of the testimony against the petitioner had been taken, except that on November 10th a conference was permitted. On the 17th the attorney for the petitioner was told over the phone to prepare to present such evidence as he desired by way of affidavits and the same would be forwarded with the report to the secretary of labor. At the close of the petitioner's examination on November 10th, she was advised:

"Q. Do you desire to designate any attorney or representative to appear for you at this hearing. A. I wish to notify Wong On, Manager of the Kwong Man Yun Comapny in this city. Q. Do you know him personally. A. My husband knows him, I do not know him."
This party was not advised, nor was counsel for petitioner permitted to be persent at this hearing. The petitioner does not understand nor speak English.

The record discloses that the order of deportation was based upon the testimony of two policemen who made the raid, which testimony shows that they had the petitioner under surveillance for some two or three weeks, and they had watched the room in which t she was arrested in this building and had seen men go in and out of the room; that on the
